['Larvae - The immature form of an insect before it undergoes metamorphosis into its adult stage, often referred to as maggots when relating to flies.', 'Chrysomyia californica - A species of blowfly whose larvae are commonly known as cheese maggots.', 'Lucilia sericata - Commonly called the green bottle fly, its larvae can be referred to as meat or carrion maggots due to their feeding habits on decaying matter.', 'Calliphoridae family - This is a large family of blowflies whose larvae are commonly known as bluebottle or housefly maggots.', 'Phormia regina - Also called the black blowfly, its larvae can be referred to as blackhouse or dogmaggots due to their feeding habits on carcasses and animal remains.', 'Diptera order - An order of insects that includes flies whose immature stage is often known as maggot when related to the fly family.', 'Maggot mass - A large group or swarm of maggots, usually found on decaying organic matter like carcasses, garbage bins, etc.', 'Fruit maggot - The larvae of fruit flies (Drosophila species), which feed primarily on ripening and rotting fruit.', 'Maggot therapy - A medical procedure in which maggots are used to clean non-healing wounds by eating away dead tissue, reducing bacterial load and promoting healing.', 'Saprophytic - An organism that feeds on decaying organic matter, such as fungi or certain types of maggots (e.g., blowfly larvae).', 'Pupa - A stage in the life cycle of insects where they transform from a larva into an adult during metamorphosis; some fly species have pupae which can be referred to as maggot-like structures before emerging as adult flies.', 'Maggot infestation - An occurrence when large numbers of maggots infiltrate and feed on organic matter, such as carcasses or food products.', "Coprophagous larvae - Larvae that primarily feed on animal feces; some fly species' larvae can be referred to as dung or manure maggots.", 'Maggot-disease vector - An insect, such as a fly, whose larvae transmit diseases (vector) through their biting and sucking habits during the feeding process on living organisms.', 'Blowfly species - A group of flies that lay eggs in dead or dying animal matter; some blowflies have maggot-like larvae, such as Calliphoridae family members.', 'Tachinid fly - An insect parasitoid whose larvae (maggots) are known to feed on other host organisms, especially caterpinas and beetles.', 'Entomophagy - The practice of eating insects; some cultures consider certain maggot species as a delicacy or food source.', 'Pupation chamber - A space where the larvae transform into pupae, often found in decomposing matter, providing habitat for various types of maggots.', 'Flesh fly (Sarcophagidae family) - Some species within this fly family are known to lay eggs on decaying meat, and their maggot-like larvae feed on the flesh.', 'Cockroach maggots - An unusual but real phenomenon where cockroach infestations cause distressed individuals to lose limbs or become disfigured; in these cases, remnants of molted exoskeletons may resemble maggot-like structures.']
